question: In the hydrosphere, where do organic rocks most commonly form?

content.source_1: About 71% of Earth’s surface is covered by water, and the global ocean contains roughly 97% of all Earth’s water by volume.
content.source_2: The hydrosphere includes all of Earth’s water reservoirs: oceans and seas, lakes and rivers, groundwater and ice, as well as surface wetlands such as swamps and bogs.
content.source_3: In the geologic record, most sedimentary organic carbon is preserved as kerogen within organic-rich marine shales deposited under anoxic conditions on continental shelves and in ocean basins.
content.source_4: Coal forms from thick accumulations of peat in waterlogged, oxygen-poor swamps and bogs; with burial and heating, peat is transformed into lignite and bituminous coal.
content.source_5: Coal is the principal sedimentary rock composed predominantly of organic matter, typically containing more than 50% organic carbon by weight.
content.source_6: Wetlands (including swamps and bogs) are components of the hydrosphere characterized by standing or saturated water that slows decomposition and promotes the accumulation of plant material.
